H0.text: The quality of food was greatly improved by Louis Pasteur’s nineteenth‑century work on pasteurization.

H1.text: The prediction of weather was greatly improved by Louis Pasteur's nineteenth‑century work on pasteurization.

H2.text: The availability of medication was greatly improved by Louis Pasteur's nineteenth‑century work on pasteurization.

H3.text: The effectiveness of vaccinations was greatly improved by Louis Pasteur’s nineteenth-century work on pasteurization.

A4.text: Pasteur patented the process, to fight the 'diseases' of wine, in 1865. The method became known as pasteurization, and was soon applied to beer and milk.

A5.text: Pasteur's works are credited with saving millions of lives through the developments of vaccines for rabies and anthrax.

A6.text: Pasteurization is named after the French microbiologist Louis Pasteur, whose research in the 1860s demonstrated that thermal processing would deactivate unwanted microorganisms in wine.

A7.text: Pasteurization was originally used as a way of preventing wine and beer from souring, and it would be many years before milk was pasteurized.
